reviewText: I just stayed up until almost 2 AM to finish this game, and I wasn't disappointed. Essentially, if you love retro JRPGs, you'll enjoy this. Game play is standard turn-based, abilities are gained by exploration, there are TONS of items to pimp out your characters, and the ending is pretty solid. As far as negatives go, the writing is average, I'd say (the love story could have been fleshed out to great effect), and some of the puzzles seemed a tad glitchy. The labyrinths teeter on the line of challenging and rage-quit inducing, individual players may vary on how they feel about it. You don't get other playable characters until later in the game, though your main character is pretty beastly on his own.\n\nOn the whole, I really enjoyed this game; it reminded me in the best ways of the early Final Fantasy games, and I can't wait to play the sequel!

reviewText:
I would definitely recommend Labyronia, it is not without issues but these are far outweighed by its successes. The combat, world, and addiction to levelling your character are all very solid. Reminding me of Mystic Quest(one of the old FF games, renamed for some reason... I think). So far I've yet to pick up any companions but there is space for two by the look of it, will be nice when I finally get one. Much of the combat and movement around the world feels refreshing fast compared to the old games of this type, falling somewhere in between those and Half minute Hero. Far less random encounters hindering your progress and far less long battles for little XP reward, all plus points in my view.

The controls are a little bit counter intuitive when played with an Xbox 360 pad, walking done via the left thumb stick and the menu's etc done via the D-Pad. You get used to this quickly and in some ways it actually adds to the retro feel but I would like the option of doing it all on one.

The enemies lack animation, though all magics and attacks have nice effects representing them, the werewolf warp effect being one to avoid if you have a problem with strobes. For £2 or less this is to be expected, asset creation is extremely time intensive and every frame of animation pretty much doubles the load, hopefully enough people will buy this to give them both the incentive and the capital to address this in future releases.

All in all Labyronia is well worth the asking price for anyone wanting a solid slice of retro style JRPG action!

Disclosure: Received review copy

RpgMaker game that has a somewhat classical JRPG setting but does things differently by having a world that is literally a labyrinth. For me this is a hard game to review as i must confess classical JRPG games with all their clichés dont have a chance in my eyes with their worn out mechanics and this game comes close to this category. So is it different enough? Yes, so it seems after some hours of gameplay.

The most defining feature of the game is the Map of the world that is literaly a labyrinth. Lots of back tracking and figuring out routes.  Combat is hard and there is lots of it once you start to explore the world map and lots of grinding for experience. Game has a tendency to show you that you just took a wrong turn by sending unbeatable monsters in your way.  Many monsters will hit you with status attacks and kill you. It also goes the other way around and this makes combat one of the better designed feature in the game. Abilities are learned with 'cues' that are scattered around the map. Books can be found during the travels that explain the story. Pretty straightforward actually.

I am really on the fence with this game. It is a new kind of blast from the past with a hardcore heart built on a old game engine.

Buyer beware. Look closely to what you are about to buy before getting this. There is nothing casual about this title so prepare for a tough adventure where no one holds your hand and tells what to do.

reviewText:
If you've played the old Final Fantasy titles, Shining Force, or old school RPGs - this game will feel very nostalgic.

It gives the same sense of reward for being attentive, thorough, and patient. I finished it in one go, split between 2 days. Was it a game worth the time? Definitely. Otherwise I wouldn't have put in the hours. Was it a game worth for the price? (I paid half because it was on sale) Yes. Easily 18+ hours if you're a fan of puzzles and exploration.

But be warned, if you're the kind who likes being spoon fed on where to go and being strung along on every game mechanic - this game is not for you.

This game literally throws you in with no tutorial. There is a story that progresses, but its minor and most of the time you'll be too preoccupied on trying to find just that small bit of information, or clue, to help you proceed. The story itself isn't polished. I myself cringed at a few script dialogues and cliched instances. But it is one that was unique in its own and one that carried me towards the end.

Overall, it is a good game for its price and the effort put into it. Just don't expect Square Enix level of content because it isn't. But it does have the soul of one,

reviewText:
Recently having finished Labyronia RPG, this classic game is one of the most challenging and yet enjoyable RPGs I have ever played.  Upon first glance, it appears to be a basic RPG where you have the opportunity to explore areas, engage in battles, etc., and although this game does have those elements, there are other elements that make it unique from other such similar games.

Basically, you start off with your one main party member (Arres) who doesn't appear to have much of a history.  All he knows is that he has a mission to complete although he doesn't know the reason (which, of course, is later revealed as you progress).  As you get to explore new areas, you'll find out that the way to learn new magic skills is unique.  In most RPGs, you learn new skills by simply leveling up.  However, in Labyronia, you learn new skills through cues.  Basically, these are items that you have to touch as you explore new areas and certain cues can only be used for certain party members.

As in most RPGs, you have the chance to earn money by defeating monsters and that money can be used to buy better weapons and equipment.  Also, there are two additional party members that can be recruited although that happens quite late in the game.  I did find that aspect to be a little annoying although considering the storyline, I can understand now why that had to happen.

A very noticeable element of this game is the implementation of labyrinths (or very complicated mazes).  They make the game challenging and although I would consider myself to be pretty adept when it comes to playing RPGs, the labyrinths were quite confusing so I had difficulty at times figuring out which way to go.  However, as I have completed the game, I was able to figure them out eventually.

There is a lot to explore and figure out in Labyronia aside from simply following the main quest.  I took the time to explore the optional elements such as the fire labyrinth, which wasn't required to complete the game but doing so gave me additional useful items.  It's definitely worth it to take the time to explore as many areas as possible, to get the most out of this game.

For the price, Labyronia is definitely worth adding to your Steam library, especially if you're a fan of RPGs and you want a challenge.  Also, this game cannot be completed quickly so it's worth taking a look.  ^^

reviewText:
For costing just a few bucks, this game was pretty good. An ambitious setting, solid combat, and unique mechanics kept me playing even when the puzzles had me flustered.

You can tell the creators spent a lot of time dreaming up the world of Labyronia, with a history of war, magic, gods, and monsters to discover as you play. Some details seem superfluous, while you may want to keep others in mind if you want to progress. Talk to every NPC, read every book, and examine everything that looks even slightly out of place. You'll find that rewards await the diligent investigator in the form of quest items, spells and abilities, and treasure.

The combat is simple enough, with most enemies sporting elemental weaknesses that you find by setting them on fire and such. There is a difficulty curve that can be quite steep if you don't take some time to grind a level here and there. The acquisition of the second and third party members is relatively close together fairly late in the game, which trivialized several battles but made up for it near the end of the game, when combining abilities is almost essential to prevail.

Cues are in-game locations and objects that serve as skill books, with each cue teaching a spell or ability to a certain party member. Keep each cue you find in mind, as you may not be able to use it the first time you run across it. Some are for abilities you might never use, but others are pretty much required to beat the game. With a wealth of items and several tiers of gear, you'll upgrade at a nice pace. Since the best gear is found in the world and money isn't really ever an issue past the beginning, it's easy enough to dilute the difficulty by buying stacks of health potions and revives and whittling away at stronger enemies while chugging healing drinks.

The puzzles ranged in difficulty from that was a puzzle?" to "there is no way this is a puzzle
recommended:
and I had to look up the solution once or twice because I'm bad and I should feel bad. But you shouldn't feel bad if you have to. As you may have guessed from the name, there are several labyrinths involved in this game. Another, less obvious theme is that of fractals. These two concepts serve as the foundation for the design and aesthetic of the world, for better or worse. You'll wind your way through a labyrinth, spot that chest sitting just out of reach on another spur of land, and wonder where you had to turn three intersections back to get to it. Likewise, you'll wonder what lay in the center of this strange pattern of terrain and go back and forth to find an entrance and wriggle your way through, usually to a prize.

A few of my gripes were that some areas were just too big, with a lot of empty space you have to run through, usually while you're backtracking from a dead end. All of the quest items are only used once to get past a specific obstacle, which was a bummer for me at first. After getting these shoes that let me walk on lily pads, you think I would be able to walk across all the lily pads, and not just the one floating in front of the door of a shrine I need to burglarize. Many puzzles could have easiliy incorporated elements that would put these items to use so that when you find one it doesn't just get used once and lay forgotten in the key items tab of your inventory. Even some of the usable items were literally useless, except to provide flavor. I thought that maybe this drakna cigar or whatever might have a use somewhere down the line, perhaps to trade with an NPC, but apparently it's just for when the hero gets to jonesing for a smoke. Sure, it probably restores some (of what replaces) mana, but I never noticed. It's the same sort of thing with several other items. At the end of the day, all you need are the potions that fullly restore health, the ones for mana, and the revive items once you get party members.

Labyronia is a great game, especially considering the price. If you can get it on sale, even better. It's several hours of puzzling, fighting, and storytelling on par with a more expensive game, with just a few drawbacks to test your patience.

reviewText:
Labyronia is a really good, classic JRPG that should satisfy fans of the genre. The music is really catchy in some areas in the game and makes the experience pleasant throughout. The art direction in the battle scenes is excellent. The dialogue is well thought out and often entertaining - I liked that the world of Labyronia was very consistent and had a history behind it which reflected the locales you explored. There are also lots of things to read which added more context to the world without being superfluous - I just couldn't help myself by reading all of the books in the environment.

The battles are strategic and generally quite balanced throughout the game. I really only had to grind at the very start of the game to build up my character, afterwhich the battles scaled very smoothly and were still challenging. The game rewards thorough exploration, most of your magic skills are obtained by exploring areas and finding cues which are contained in distinguished objects and monsters. Much of the puzzles and game progression is driven by your ability to connect various clues in the environments and dialogues - I rarely found myself in a quandary about what to do next.

Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10.

Also, I beat Bastion before I started this game, and I would easily choose Labyronia over Bastion anyday. Bastion was good, but not nearly as strategic and open as Labyronia.

This game is surprisingly addictive, offering a good blend of story-driven content, regular fight scenes, hidden loot and the ability to trade in towns. If you are a fan of Ultima and other early fantasy titles, you should enjoy this game.

From the start, the encounters with monsters prove quite challenging. If you choose to fight rather than escape, it is worth saving often to avoid death.

In my opinion the graphics look best when playing zoomed out in a window, rather than full screen (toggle using F5/F6). The soundtrack keeps things interesting and, at times, the music choices really add to the atmosphere of the scenes. The controls are also very simple to use.

The only downside I can foresee is that once the quests are complete, there is limited replay-ability. On the plus-side though, there is Labyronia 2 and Mysteria to follow.

At such a low price, Labyronia is really worth exploring.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Labyronia RPG with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

Before I even began playing, I already had a gripe: Labyronia was not built for HD. Yes, I know that the art style mimics that of old SNES RPGs but that is no excuse for looking absolutely janky when in fullscreen. Following up the poor initial presentation was a story that was... cheesy? I find it difficult to accurately describe it. There are Gods who have a super power ancient artifact, non-gods are at war with them, non-gods lose and the world is fractured into X number of factions/regions, etc. It’s not quite “cookie-cutter” but very generic for these types of games.

Speaking of broad stereotyping of RPG maker games, the opening scene-as if following the cliche template bullet for bullet-begins with you waking up in your bedroom. At least others give some quasi-convincing exposition for why you of all the inhabitants of the world are going to begin a journey to defeat the prior specified evil. Labyronia opens with “Time to fight this evil, which I am qualified to do because I have magic and skills. Let me get my sword out of the chest.” I don’t think a game has ever motivated me less.

So what was my gameplay experience like? I wandered around the room and clicked on things (like you do) bringing me to the first straw: the default key binding for interacting with anything is O (B for 360 pads). Yes this is a almost pointless gripe, but I was curled up and comfy in bed with no desire to get up to the keyboard to remap it. I sucked it up and headed out side, using the button ubiquitously responsible for cancel/escape to talk to people. In the process I managed to open my inventory, a critical RPG feature which I have no idea how to access since the only button pressed thus far has been O/B. This led to the acquisition of straw number two. I got out of bed determined to figure out all the buttons once and for all via the F1 menu. This was the most horrendous mapping interface I have ever seen; gamepad buttons were mapped to random letters with no explanation as to what they actually did. I couldn’t be bothered to decrypt this menu so I returned to the game for the final straw. I COULD NOT leave the inventory screen. For those who are thinking “Oh, you just don’t have the button mapped to the controller correctly”, you’re right. Do you know where else it wasn’t mapped? ANYWHERE. I pushed every-and I do mean every- button on the keyboard and mouse and nothing did more than give me a rude buzzer.

RPG Maker shovel-ware is a dime a dozen (often literally) and unless you offer something mindblowing out of the gate, any small flaw or defect can become a dealbreaker. I have a key for Labyronia RPG 2 which is next on my roster; here’s hoping they have polished it up considerably.

Labyronia... Labrynth.
That one key word: Labrynth, already tells you what you're in for.

Overall for the price of 50 cents for this game and it's sequel.. I'd give it a 7/10.

reviewText:
FIRST, while the game is inspired by FF and CT, by no means is it the same as them. Labyronia brings to the table a unique fighting fantasy game which is both challenging and exciting.

I made the mistake of thinkining that this was one of those games which you could finish in a single sitting.. THE JOKE WAS ON ME. You cannot finish this game in a single sitting and you WILL BE FRUSTRATED at several intersections while you try to figure out where to go and what to do (although that shouldn't take you very long).

ANYWAY, there is much that I say about this game, lets begin:

The game in itself has a wonderful storyline with a fantastic way of slowly revealing bits of information to keep the player engaged. If you're into mysteries, this game will keep you on the edge of your seat, determined to find out just why the hell you're doing what you are. DID I MENTION THAT THERE ARE FLASHBACKS? FLASHBACKS!

While the game doesn't feature the baddies health or level meters, the game does give you a fair amount of warning if a creature is too powerful for you to handle at that moment and lets you decently level up as you progress through the game. I doubt you'll need to grind through this game (unless you've been skimping out on all those encounters!). Also, the game warns you when you have to fight bosses and there's usually always a save point somewhere nearby that you can use. Its safe to say that if you spot a save point, you're probably going to need it so make sure to save up.

Speaking of which, the battle style is incredibly simple. You don't have a 'battle meter' in the game so your turns are mostly based on your Agility levels. YEAH, GO BACK TO THOSE GAMES WHERE YOU HAD TO PREP YOUR CHARACTERS STAT POINTS.

The game isn't as open world as it may seem at first, there are fixed boundries that loop as you pass through, AND THERE ARE NO GUIDE MAPS OR SIGNIFICANT MARKED LOCATIONS, which makes areas really seem as a Labyrinth. However, it doesn't take very long (unless you have the memory of a goldfish like I do) to figure out the layout of the area once you're in there (except for that Desert of Illusions. WHAT A ♥♥♥♥♥).

ITEMS. While you may think that the game lacks items and armory, I found whatever available to be sufficient for the gameplay. Also, in Labyronia, don't sell all the weapons and armour just because you think you're not going to need them, some of those items have special properties which you're going to seriously need later on.. UNLESS YOU GRINDED TO A SUPER HIGH LEVEL.

There is still so much more I could say about this game, BUT I WON'T. I don't want to ruin the excitement and fun out of the game so just purchase is and play it. Its worth a lot more than the price you're paying for it.

I  have played the game a lot more since the past review, and I gotta say, I have had even more of my mind blown. Here is what you can expect from Labyronia RPG:
Adrenaline inducing fights
A heist mystery that despite being a Big Lipped Alligator Moment, is entertaining
An engaging story (once you get around 2 it)
Fun Party Members with their own pros and cons (Once you get around 2 them)
The incredible usage of the cue system, which the game states you don't need but you will spend hours looking for.
And freaking huge maps. Really. You will not believe how huge these are. The game is kind of RPG Maker Skyrim.
The devs have done way too much, but in a good way. At one point you are in a gigantic desert, and there are not only various NPCs, each coping with heat induced insanity in seperate ways, but there is enough fun little weirdness going on. A living miniature boat takes you to a cryptic creepy clown, there is a Paper Mario type quiz, and a fun little puzzle. The devs have also put together one of the most complete and interesting worlds in an RPG Maker game, and not just map wise. There is an abundance of books that can tell you details about the world and the lore, ranging from personal notes to histories. I can truly say this game, which uses generic rpg maker random encounter enemies, is a rpg maker Final Fantasy game. 9/10.

reviewText:
The story and setting are uninspired and underdeveloped. You are given a task and that's what you get. You can find some lore books to read that attempt to flesh out the world like what has been seen in the Elder Scrolls series, but there is nothing within the game to connect that lore, so it doesn't even matter and isn't worth the time. Characters don't develop, plot doesn't develop it just advances on its own as you go forth, and the dialog is stale.

In terms of gameplay, it is the barebone standard of turn-based RPGs.  Having one character for more than half the game makes some status effects game ending cheap shots. Instead of having magic be a level-based unlock, there is a gimmicky cue system where you must find strange things in your environment to interact with to learn new spells. It is very unnecessary and a pain when new party members finally join for you will be off backtracking to all the areas you visited that had cues you couldn't use. Considering each area is rather small and cues being blatantly obvious, what little exploration is there is forced and uninteresting.

The graphics and sound are fine for what they are and I love pixel art, especially where RPGs are concerned. I don't personally care about stock assets considering the price of the game is so low; I understand not everyone is a born Edward Hopper. I'm more interested in plot and setting in these regards and that is where the game ultimately failed for me.

Labyronia doesn't feel like a polished game. It seems like a good start to a campaign, despite the formulaic premise, but lacks any real meat to make you care about anything to keep pressing on, despite the short game length. It's too bare-boned and lifeless as a whole for me to regard it in a positive light.

reviewText:
I'm a person that loves RPG Maker games; my avatar's the Batter from OFF, for crying out loud. I enjoy going on rpgmaker.net and seeing the things that some people can make. A lot of people stereotype RPG Maker games to be low effort when there's just as many games that have care put into them, with original graphics and everything.

But this game - and all other games by the creator - symbolizes that stereotype.

Labryonia just seems to use the default assets provided by the RPG Maker VX Ace engine along with some resources that seem to be pulled from resource packs. The only original things seem to be those book pages you find lying around every now and then, but even then they all just seem like text pasted onto a page template. As for the story, it's pretty much humdrum elemental stuff. If you're in for an incredibly basic JRPG experience, sure, it's fine, but as some games like To the Moon demonstrates, RPG Maker could be used to tell incredible stories, and sadly Labryonia is as bland as it is uninspired.

My play time looks short, yes, but the beginning parts of the game looks like an omen of mediocrity to come. Allow me to rant. The first, real dungeon of the game is the Water Labyrinth. The first dungeon of a game should be easy and interesting (though not overly interesting - the real fascinating stuff should be saved for toward the end), but this dungeon is neither. It's like the Hell Maze from Yume Nikki except somehow worse, and it's real easy to get lost an/or hit dead-ends. The whole dungeon is blue. It's an eyesore. There is little varience in dungeon design as well, save for the occasional red crystal. See, you're supposed to find all these red crystals to open the door to the boss... but of course these crystals are hidden all throughout the dungeon so you'll be stuck with the tedious and eye-killing task of walking around the badly designed dungeon. There are two reprieves though, I'll have to admit. Thankfully encounters in dungeons are on-screen and not random encounters; if they were, I would have dropped the game right then and there. Secondly, there is an item that gives you regenerating AP (the game's version of MP), so you'll be able to heal off any damage you take. If you're sincerely playing this game, I recommend picking this up. Meanwhile, the actual boss fight is manageable - if extremely tedious like everything else.

Now that is not a good way to start a game off. Games should ease you into the experience, not bore or frustrate you into senselessness, but Labryonia did just that. I'm honestly shocked that this game has such a good rating on Steam. If rpgmaker.net had more users and momentum, I'm sure that the game would have gotten completely savaged like most other low-effort works. In all honesty, the only reason why I picked this and the second game up is because it was dirt cheap and I'm a sucker for easy Steam cards.

Do you want a good RPG Maker game? This is not one. I recommend going on RPG Maker sites and poking around for anything good. I personally recommend Grist of Flies and HOME if you're looking for anything recent-ish. Want to throw your money at an RPG Maker game? Why not give Lisa: The Painful RPG and To the Moon a go instead of this?

But then again, this game is dirt cheap, so why not?

(If there is one thing to praise about this game though, I like the idea of gaining skills from certain sources. If this was a good game this would push the player to explore, providing incentive beyond a chest full of gold or items. Too bad this isn't a good game.)

reviewText:
I'm a person that loves RPG Maker games; my avatar's the Batter from OFF, for crying out loud. I enjoy going on rpgmaker.net and seeing the things that some people can make. A lot of people stereotype RPG Maker games to be low effort when there's just as many games that have care put into them, with original graphics and everything.

But this game - and all other games by the creator - symbolizes that stereotype.

Labryonia just seems to use the default assets provided by the RPG Maker VX Ace engine along with some resources that seem to be pulled from resource packs. The only original things seem to be those book pages you find lying around every now and then, but even then they all just seem like text pasted onto a page template. As for the story, it's pretty much humdrum elemental stuff. If you're in for an incredibly basic JRPG experience, sure, it's fine, but as some games like To the Moon demonstrates, RPG Maker could be used to tell incredible stories, and sadly Labryonia is as bland as it is uninspired.

My play time looks short, yes, but the beginning parts of the game looks like an omen of mediocrity to come. Allow me to rant. The first, real dungeon of the game is the Water Labyrinth. The first dungeon of a game should be easy and interesting (though not overly interesting - the real fascinating stuff should be saved for toward the end), but this dungeon is neither. It's like the Hell Maze from Yume Nikki except somehow worse, and it's real easy to get lost an/or hit dead-ends. The whole dungeon is blue. It's an eyesore. There is little varience in dungeon design as well, save for the occasional red crystal. See, you're supposed to find all these red crystals to open the door to the boss... but of course these crystals are hidden all throughout the dungeon so you'll be stuck with the tedious and eye-killing task of walking around the badly designed dungeon. There are two reprieves though, I'll have to admit. Thankfully encounters in dungeons are on-screen and not random encounters; if they were, I would have dropped the game right then and there. Secondly, there is an item that gives you regenerating AP (the game's version of MP), so you'll be able to heal off any damage you take. If you're sincerely playing this game, I recommend picking this up. Meanwhile, the actual boss fight is manageable - if extremely tedious like everything else.

Now that is not a good way to start a game off. Games should ease you into the experience, not bore or frustrate you into senselessness, but Labryonia did just that. I'm honestly shocked that this game has such a good rating on Steam. If rpgmaker.net had more users and momentum, I'm sure that the game would have gotten completely savaged like most other low-effort works. In all honesty, the only reason why I picked this and the second game up is because it was dirt cheap and I'm a sucker for easy Steam cards.

Do you want a good RPG Maker game? This is not one. I recommend going on RPG Maker sites and poking around for anything good. I personally recommend Grist of Flies and HOME if you're looking for anything recent-ish. Want to throw your money at an RPG Maker game? Why not give Lisa: The Painful RPG and To the Moon a go instead of this?

But then again, this game is dirt cheap, so why not?

(If there is one thing to praise about this game though, I like the idea of gaining skills from certain sources. If this was a good game this would push the player to explore, providing incentive beyond a chest full of gold or items. Too bad this isn't a good game.)

reviewText:
So like others before have stated, I wanted to like this game. I really did, but there were far too many cons in just over an hour of playtime that gradually depleted that hope until all I was left with was a game over screen screen prompting me to return to the source and try my luck again, which unfortunately, you will be needing a lot of if you attempt to play this game.

First I will start with the pros that I found.

+ The sounds and music are very well done, and are reminiscent to Secret of Mana in regards to music quality and Final Fantasy: Mystic Quest in regards to the sound effects, especially your sword attack.
+ When you talk to some NPCs they show a small character profile of them which is very well drawn.
+ The first and only village I visited, which while small, was well drawn out and I liked seeing some of the animations, including the flowers blowing in the wind, and the birds and butterflies moving around. It definitely added a bit of charm to the otherwise static world.

Now I have to move on to the cons and before anybody chooses to downvote my review, please take into account that this is my opinion.

- When I booted up the game it started off in a small (Minesweeper) size window that was hard to see, so I found the option to move it into fullscreen which upgraded the screen size about 1/3 more which wasn't much better but it at least made it viewable. Unfortunately, while playing, the screen constantly flickered and glitched while I moved slowly, I might add around the overworld, which after a few minutes began to hurt my eyes. There is an option in the settings where you can decrease the flickering, but after clicking it, it didn't do much to help.
- My character moves as slow as a snail in the overworld map to the point where I would pray that I wouldn't encounter an enemy while I could see the lone village at the edge of my screen. Although, his pace quickly changes in specific area screens with the click of the Shift button making it more bearable, but still making me dread trudging once again around the overworld.
- The first battle I had after leaving my house was with a Python enemy, and so I thought I got this, but was sorely mistaken after getting knocked out from three hits without even the knowledge of knowing how much damage I inflicted on it. No enemy health bars makes the battles annoying to the point where I had to keep track of how much health each of the six enemy types I encountered had in my head and relied once again on luck to strike back with the correct amount of damage in the fewest amount of turns.
- No item drops, only gold which becomes pointless after a short while due to no variance in weapons, armor or items available in the first town. How can the Wool Robe be worth more MDG (Whatever that is) that the Leather Tunic and the tunic only increases your defense by 2 points? Really? How does that make sense?
- I must have crossed the first bridge at least thirty times farming for experience, which you will need to do right off the bat, trust me, and no matter how fast I was, or well versed with my timing, could not sneak up on the lone enemy! Almost every RPG, especially 90's era RPGs have allowed the character/ player to sneak up and get a surprise attack, why is that not an option now?
- Some of the design choices that were made baffle me, like for instance, on the first bridge, there are holes in it which reveal water beneath that is a solid blue color, like something straight out of MS Paint, but the wood paneling of the bridge is very well textured and designed. That is odd but whatever, eventually get to the Northern Bridge seperating you from the Ice World and the water surrounding the bridge is textured and even animated. Why the difference? It doesn't make any bit of sense.
- What you need to be doing and where you need to go are muddled and ultimately left out for you to figure out on your own. Tried heading into the Elven forest but got sniped by the first enemy I encountered, which was an Elven Archer. Okay, let's try the Ice World, but alas, can't break rocks yet and got attacked by a gang of six ice bats all doing 30+ damage each turn which will dwindle your health pretty quickly even after reaching level 5, so I had to flee. Let's try going left towards Jenise which I figured out was the name of a city and not a woman after talking to a bald NPC in the Cold Shoulder" Pub. Good luck trying to make it to the cave that you are supposed to travel through to the city before an Orc destroys you with their critical hits that come into play 1/2 the time. This leads me to believe that I better start grinding away or dash my chances of progressing in the game

reviewText:
Pretty simple, but still quite fun RPG. The game uses some basic RPGMaker assets, such as the mountains and trees, but the art is much better than a lot of the custom assets in other RPGMaker games I have played. And I really appreciate that it doesn't spend the first half hour of the game on exposition.

You start the game, you grab your sword, and you go out into the world.

This is a very good way to make a game IMO.

The combat is punishing and attacks have decent animations.

Minor annoyances are that the games seems to have no option screen to rebind keys or change resolution outside of the typical RPGMaker F1 keybind. Resolution is limited to fullscreen or a small window. On my 360 pad the action key was on X by default rather than A, which took longer to figure out than it should have as I assumed my controller was just being stupid instead of trying all the buttons like a sane human being. I would've preferred to change the keybindings in game, but I can deal with the RPGMaker menu.

Overall I'd say it's worth your time if you don't like handholding and are a fan of RPGMaker titles. Solid game and pretty darn cheap even without a sale.

I was looking forward to playing this RPG as the videos and screenshots looked pretty good to me.  I booted the game up and was greeted by a super tiny window and title screen.  I decided to jump right into it anyway, and after a short intro screen the game introduced me to the Options menu.

Great, I thought.  I can finally get the game to run in full screen. Well, the Fullscreen option did not work without a ton of screen flickering which made my eyes hurt.  Luckily I saw an option in the menu to reduce screen flickering, so I figured I'd try that one.  Nope, the option to reduce screen flickering did not help alleviate this problem.

So then I decided, I'd turn down the resolution on my monitor, and give it another shot in a slightly less super tiny window.  I did a little bit of exploring, checking out the first nearby town and talking to some of the people.  After a couple of random battles, and visiting a shop I decided I wanted to adjust my control options.

Adjusting the control options isn't a straightforward task.  It allows you to re-map your controller to different keyboard letters in the game, but doesn't actually say what each button does.  I figured I'd just re-map the buttons a little bit and I'd have it set up to a somewhat tolerable level to continue to check out the game some more.  Unfortunately after I re-mapped the buttons, the game bugged out and was unplayable.

After booting the game back up another time, and confirming that my previous control settings were saved, I decided to plunge in one more time.  The first thing I noticed was that the changes I made in the controls screen didn't actually make any difference in the game, my controller still did the same things.  So, again I continued to play the game further constantly telling myself I'd just have to get used to the controls because I really wanted to check out this game!

After wandering around for another 10 minutes and finding the first place I was supposed to go, I died valiantly in battle due to pressing the wrong button.  Then I decided that I was not interested in this game any more. As for the rest of the game I haven't played enough of it to review.

Labyronia RPG is a classic turn-based RPG in the style of Chrono Trigger and the earlier Final Fantasy titles. As an RPG fan, there is little not to like in this title. There is world-adventuring, dungeon-crawling and puzzle-solving. There are small villages and larger towns, each with their own style and feel. There is lore to the game, revealed in books and scraps of paper throughout the game. Hidden in caves and dungeons all over the map are rare items and secrets, and players should take note of anything unusual they see to come back to.

A fundamental aspect of the combat are Auras, derived from Cues found around the game world. An example of this might be an angry chef, who gives you the Cue for a flame attack. These Cues are scattered all over the place and serve as a fun and lasting impetus for players to really explore every nook and cranny of the world.

The story is sparse and anodyne at first - stay with it. It really picks up, especially towards the end. I feel like the developers really caught the atmosphere of world-changing events well. The climactic boss battle felt grounded in the game world's events - not only difficult, but meaningful. It felt as if the outcome mattered, and the sense of reward when beating something which makes you feel that way is exactly what I play videogames for.

The music was great, even the omnipresent world music I never tired of. The enemies are varied and interesting, a far cry from the re-coloured skins of Final Fantasy eg., and helped give the dungeons they inhabit their own distinct atmospheres.

My only negatives with this game were as follows: the lack of direction - often I was very unsure where I was going and what to, and I could see how this might put a more casual gamer off; the confusing maps (looking at you, frozen field, forest and desert) that take far longer to traverse than should be necessary, and SPOILER  the baffling decision to only unlock your second and third party members in the last fifth of the game. Why?!  And then MEGA SPOILER  to lose the third member before the final boss battle! So you take pains to prepare, building a balanced team, only to lose a member for the duration of the fight. I laughed when it happened, it was so unexpected and silly.

Some players may also have trouble with the game's difficulty, particularly at the start. All I can say is to stick with it. Longtime RPGers should have no problem, and more casual gamers will certainly find that grinding for a level or two or finding a new Cue will make once-impossible foes much more beatable.

The story takes place in Labyronia: a world filled with natural labyrinths (of course) which have been created by the four elemental gods in order to punish the humans and their rebellious wizards. And along with the labyrinths, monsters appeard throughout the lands. Yeah, this doesn't sound THAT bad. Now, 50 years after the creation of the labyrinths our main character Arres wakes up one morning and decides to finally save the world by obtaining the 4 elemental crystals and kick the gods' asses. This is were the game starts..

Don't get me wrong. The story is indeed a big cliche and there are lots and lots of other issues, like when you have no exact idea what you have to do most of the time.
